content:
Hi!
I got caught by Validator 6, because I only checked for pieces' alignment, ignoring their order along the line.
Test 6 passed. B is masking the attack.
But Validator 6 failed. My code believed that Q masked R and R masked Q. I could fix having a look at your contribution, but a beginner would not be allowed to do that :-)
Maybe you could add some test to check for the line of sight rule.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Took me around 20 minutes to come up with a working solution. Suitable problem for a medium level puzzle
Is there a fixed-width font you can use for the examples in the "Statement" section?  Not a dealbreaker, but it would make those layouts easier to see as chessboards.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very intriguing for a Medium puzzle! :)
looks good
Nice level of difficulty with the blocking mechanics

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This was fun to solve and has a degree of difficulty with pieces blocking each other

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Doesn't seem to me to be much more difficult than the first part ... there are only 2 figures that you have to test. in addition, in the first example, is the queen e7 able to attack the king b4?

it would be better either to give the opponent a move or to give yourself a figure with a move. to test whether a chess or a block would be possible.

One suggestion to make it more different than part 1. There could be four possible answers instead of two:
- checkmate (check and the king cannot move)
- check (check and the king can still move)
- stalemate (not check and the king cannot move)
- no check (neither check nor stalemate)

If it is too complex, you could decide to have only three options by adding checkmate *or* stalemate.

Note that if you decide to follow this idea, I would recommend to rewrite the description to consider the reader as the next player to move.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle. Continue of series

Change K in k please. It's really disturbing. Add also the opponent King K.
You are about to get a good puzzle.

Next one should be. Check Mate In 1, 2, 3 Move.
This one is too easy. Even it's interesting. Don't be shy to add challenge.

Hi DrQuarius.
This is good, but as Dwarfie pointed out not different enough from part-1 to be exciting. 
Maybe changing the question to something like 'can the king move, and where?' will force us to change more than a few lines of code.

Hey DrQuarius

I think blocking is ok in for medium.  Both Validator 2 and Test 3 have that block and result should be No Check

Also consider use lowercase k for king to make a feeling like checking opponents king. Like lowercase pieces are black and uppercases are white

You doubled this contribution.

Please let me know what you think of the difficulty here? Please do part 1 first https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/is-the-king-in-check-part-1 before judging this 'too hard'.

I could make this more difficult by forcing players to actually consider enemy pieces able to 'block eachother's checks'. I felt this was a bit too hard for 'Medium' but if others disagree, I can change the submission.

Shouldn't the second validator be 'no check' before adding enemy pieces? Before adding enemy pieces to block you, your own pieces should block you first. It wouldn't be that harder and would make more sense, in my opinion. :)
(and yes, even if the pieces can jump over)

looks like you have not missed the joke in  the statement 
"ignoring pieces that may be 'in the way' - i.e. the enemy pieces can all 'jump' over each other to attack the King"

consequence : the solution could be exactly the same as the part-1's.... at worst , you'll have to add 3-4 lines ... not really interesting

i asked myself if part 2 would not be superfluous to me when i saw "part 1" in title of previous contribution (there is already lots of chess on CG)
unfortunately it seems so ...

I have updated the challenge based on some other suggestions that thought allowing blocking of checks would make this hard enough to be worth a 'Part 2'. Allied pieces can now block each other's checks and I found changing the code quite difficult (took me about 30 minutes, mainly due to figuring out a way to check for diagonal blocking). I hope this is now hard enough.

'Can the king move and where?' is a great challenge! I think I'd like to stick to "Is the King in check?" but I welcome you to translate this submission into "Can the king move and where?" if you'd like. :)
Mate in 1, 2, 3 Move! You're welcome to make Part 3 if you can figure out how to make a checkmate-finding algorithm on CodinGame.com, I certainly would find that too difficult myself. :P

Hmm, I will definitely change K to k, but as much as adding the opponent's K would make the puzzle more "real", I think it makes it a little bit too parsing-heavy as a challenge. If others agree with you I can change though.
Thank you. :) I hope you enjoyed it.

Have you solved it? It took me an additional 30 minutes to solve for cases when a bishop or queen's diagonal check is blocked.

Checking for lateral blocking is fairly simple, but the diagonal blocking is a tough challenge. Let me know if you solve it.

Test 1 yes, the queen is checking the king diagonally and there is no block. Compare to Test 5 where the rook is blocking the check.
I understand the idea. For a player he can remove all reference to K before parsing the puzzle. But I understand the idea to keep puzzle for everyone. Like very much your puzzle.

Thanks for the feedback, both of you.

I will allow for blocking of pieces then. :)

I am definitely tempted to change the King so that it does match really PGN/FEN notation, I guess I will do so.

Edit: The King is now "k" instead of "K".

Thank you, I have updated the submission so that blocking is a factor and Validator 2 is now "No Check". I highly recommend you trying to solve it now, I found dealing with diagonal blocks to be quite challenging and spent almost 30 minutes to solve it.
